message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Knowledge and Justification
Paper Abstract: Abstract Chapter 1 starts from the tenet that the goal of cognition is the transfer of information in the form of justified true belief. The focus of this book is the development of a theory of justification in the tradition of enlightenment epistemology. Its leading idea is foundation-theoretic: to reach knowledge we must not legitimize our beliefs by external authorities but justify them by rational arguments. Early foundation-theoretic epistemology was naive, since its conception of justification required certainty. Certainty was discovered to be untenable by analytic epistemologists of the 20th century, because the justification of most of our beliefs cannot be confined to deduction from evidence, but instead requires induction and abduction which cannot convey certainty but only, at most, high probability. However, the illusion of indefeasible knowledge was not only held by premodern philosophers but is also ubiquitous in commonsense intuitions of knowledge. This is revealed by an analysis of two paradoxes of knowledge: the lottery paradox and the Gettier paradox. Both paradoxes turn out to be partially unsolvable because of tensions intrinsic to commonsense intuitions associated with knowledge. It is argued that instead of trying to rationalize incoherent intuitions, epistemology should improve the commonsense concept by transforming it into the scientific concept of a justified (true) belief whose justification makes it highly probable and reveals its error probabilities.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "Foundationalism epistemology"

Links: [{"title":"Foundationalism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foundationalism"},{"title":"Anti-foundationalism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-foundationalism"},{"title":"Reformed epistemology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reformed_epistemology"},{"title":"Virtue epistemology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtue_epistemology"},{"title":"Coherentism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coherentism"},{"title":"Regress argument (epistemology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regress_argument_(epistemology)"},{"title":"Robert Audi - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Audi"},{"title":"Laurence BonJour - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laurence_BonJour"},{"title":"Religious epistemology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Religious_epistemology"},{"title":"Foundherentism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foundherentism"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of foundationalism in epistemology:

## Definition and Core Idea

Foundationalism is an attempt to respond to the regress problem of justification in epistemology.(no content)Foundationalism holds that there are 'basic beliefs' which serve as foundations to anchor the rest of our beliefs.

## The Problem It Addresses

According to this argument, every proposition requires justification to support it, but any justification also needs to be justified itself.(no content)If this goes on ad infinitum, it is not clear how anything in the chain could be justified. Foundationalism resolves this by positing basic beliefs that are self-justifying or requireno further justification.

## Versions of Foundationalism

Classically, foundationalism had posited infallibility of basic beliefs and deductive reasoning between beliefs—a strong foundationalism. However, more moderate theories hold that indirectly justified beliefs require basic beliefs to be justified, but can be further justified by other factors.

## Historical Context

Descartes, the most famed foundationalist, discovered a foundation in the fact of his own existence and in the "clear and distinct" ideas of reason, whereas Locke found a foundation in experience.

## Main Rival Theory

The main rival of the foundationalist theory of justification is the coherence theory of justification, whereby a body of knowledge, not requiring a secure foundation, can be established by the interlocking strength of its components, like a puzzle solved without prior certainty that each small region was solved correctly.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Descartes, the most famed foundationalist, discovered a foundation in the fact of his own existence and in the "clear and distinct" ideas of reason, whereas Locke found a foundation in experience.

## Main Rival Theory

The main rival of the foundationalist theory of justification is the coherence theory of justification, whereby a body of knowledge, not requiring a secure foundation, can be established by the interlocking strength of its components, like a puzzle solved without prior certainty that each small region was solved correctly.

Web search results for query: "Enlightenment epistemology"

Links: [{"title":"Age of Enlightenment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment"},{"title":"Epistemology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistemology"},{"title":"Enlightenment philosophy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enlightenment_philosophy"},{"title":"Immanuel Kant - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Immanuel_Kant"},{"title":"Rationalism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rationalism"},{"title":"Empiricism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Empiricism"},{"title":"Romantic epistemology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Romantic_epistemology"},{"title":"Early modern philosophy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Early_modern_philosophy"},{"title":"John Locke - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Locke"},{"title":"List of intellectuals of the Enlightenment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_intellectuals_of_the_Enlightenment"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of Enlightenment epistemology:

## Core Characteristics

Enlightenment epistemology was characterized by an emphasis on reason, empirical evidence, and scientific method. There is debate about its beginning, though several historians and philosophers argue that it was marked by Descartes' 1637 philosophy of Cogito, ergo sum ("I think, therefore I am"), which shifted the epistemological basis from external authority to internal certainty.

## The Rationalism vs. Empiricism Debate

A central feature of Enlightenment epistemology was the tension between two major approaches: In a major philosophical debate during the Enlightenment, rationalism (sometimes here equated with innatism) was opposed to empiricism.(no content)Rationalists like René Descartes emphasized that knowledge is primarily innate and the intellect can directly grasp or derive logical truths; empiricists like John Locke emphasized that knowledge is not primarily innate and is best gained by careful observation of the physical world outside the mind, namely through sensory experience.

However, many Enlightenment rationalists and empiricists still made concessions to each other, and the main continental rationalists (Descartes, Spinoza, and Leibniz) were also advocates of the empirical "scientific method".

## Key Figures and Their Contributions

Philosophical foundations were laid by thinkers including René Descartes, Thomas Hobbes, Baruch Spinoza, and John Locke, whose ideas about reason, natural rights, and empirical knowledge became central to Enlightenment thought.(no content)Immanuel Kant's comprehensive and systematic works in epistemology, metaphysics, ethics, and aesthetics have made him one of the most influential and highly discussed figures in modern Western philosophy.

Web search results for query: "Abduction reasoning logic"

Links: [{"title":"Abductive reasoning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abductive_reasoning"},{"title":"Abductive logic programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abductive_logic_programming"},{"title":"Lorenzo Magnani - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lorenzo_Magnani"},{"title":"Abduction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abduct"},{"title":"Charles Sanders Peirce - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Sanders_Peirce"},{"title":"Talk:Abductive reasoning/Archive 1 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Abductive_reasoning/Archive_1"},{"title":"Inductive reasoning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inductive_reasoning"},{"title":"Talk:Abductive reasoning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Abductive_reasoning"},{"title":"Logical reasoning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logical_reasoning"},{"title":"Probabilistic logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Probability_logic"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about abduction reasoning in logic:

## Definition and Overview

Abductive reasoning (also called abduction, abductive inference, or retroduction) is a form of logical inference that seeks the simplest and most likely conclusion from a set of observations.(no content)It is also known as "inference to the best explanation", starting from an observation and reasoning to the fact explaining this observation.

## Key Characteristics

Abductive reasoning, unlike deductive reasoning, yields a plausible conclusion but does not definitively verify it, and abductive conclusions do not eliminate uncertainty or doubt.(no content)While inductive reasoning draws general conclusions that apply to many situations, abductive conclusions are confined to the particular observations in question.

## Historical Development

It was formulated and advanced by the American philosopher and logician Charles Sanders Peirce beginning in the latter half of the 19th century.(no content)Pragmatism is the logic of abduction.

## Practical Applications

In medicine, abduction can be seen as a component of clinical evaluation and judgment, with the Internist-I diagnostic system being the first AI system that covered the field of Internal Medicine and used abductive reasoning to converge on the most likely causes of patient symptoms.(no content)In intelligence analysis, analysis of competing hypotheses and Bayesian networks, probabilistic abductive reasoning is used extensively.

## Relationship to Other Forms of Reasoning

Abduction, deduction, and induction comprise a cycle understandable as a whole, with abduction hypothesizing an explanation for deduction to clarify into implications to be tested so that induction can evaluate the hypothesis.

Links: [{"title":"Deductive reasoning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deductive_reasoning"},{"title":"Deduction theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deduction_theorem"},{"title":"Natural deduction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_deduction"},{"title":"Hilbert system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hilbert_system"},{"title":"Cut-elimination theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cut-elimination_theorem"},{"title":"Peirce's law - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peirce's_law"},{"title":"Fitch notation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fitch_notation"},{"title":"Jape (software) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jape_(software)"},{"title":"Normal form (natural deduction) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Normal_form_(natural_deduction)"},{"title":"Automated reasoning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_reasoning"}]

Here are the search results for "Deduction logic":

## Overview

Deductive reasoning is the process of drawing valid inferences.(no content)An inference is valid if its conclusion follows logically from its premises, meaning that it is impossible for the premises to be true and the conclusion to be false. A classic example is: "all men are mortal" and "Socrates is a man" to the conclusion "Socrates is mortal" is deductively valid.

## Key Concepts

Deductive logic studies under what conditions an argument is valid. There are two main approaches:

- **Semantic Approach**: An argument is valid if there is no possible interpretation of the argument whereby its premises are true and its conclusion is false.

- **Syntactic Approach**: The syntactic approach focuses on rules of inference, that is, schemas of drawing a conclusion from a set of premises based only on their logical form. There are various rules of inference, such as modus ponens and modus tollens.

## Proof Systems

Several formal systems have been developed to handle deductive reasoning:

- Natural deduction is a type of proof system based on simple and self-evident rules of inference.
- In logic and proof theory, natural deduction is a kind of proof calculus in which logical reasoning is expressed by inference rules closely related to the "natural" way of reasoning.
- Fitch notation is a method of presenting natural deduction proofs in propositional calculus and first-order logics using a structured, line-by-line format that explicitly shows assumptions, inferences, and their scope. It was invented by Frederic Brenton Fitch in the 1930s.

Here are the search results for "Deduction logic":

## Overview

Deductive reasoning is the process of drawing valid inferences.(no content)An inference is valid if its conclusion follows logically from its premises, meaning that it is impossible for the premises to be true and the conclusion to be false. A classic example is: "all men are mortal" and "Socrates is a man" to the conclusion "Socrates is mortal" is deductively valid.

## Key Concepts

Deductive logic studies under what conditions an argument is valid. There are two main approaches:

- **Semantic Approach**: An argument is valid if there is no possible interpretation of the argument whereby its premises are true and its conclusion is false.

- **Syntactic Approach**: The syntactic approach focuses on rules of inference, that is, schemas of drawing a conclusion from a set of premises based only on their logical form. There are various rules of inference, such as modus ponens and modus tollens.

## Proof Systems

Several formal systems have been developed to handle deductive reasoning:

- Natural deduction is a type of proof system based on simple and self-evident rules of inference.
- In logic and proof theory, natural deduction is a kind of proof calculus in which logical reasoning is expressed by inference rules closely related to the "natural" way of reasoning.
- Fitch notation is a method of presenting natural deduction proofs in propositional calculus and first-order logics using a structured, line-by-line format that explicitly shows assumptions, inferences, and their scope. It was invented by Frederic Brenton Fitch in the 1930s.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Justified true belief"

Links: [{"title":"Gettier problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gettier_problem"},{"title":"Justification (epistemology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Justification_(epistemology)"},{"title":"Infinite regress - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regress_argument"},{"title":"Evidentialism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evidentialism"},{"title":"Epistemology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistemology"},{"title":"Definitions of knowledge - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Definitions_of_knowledge"},{"title":"Swamping problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swamping_problem"},{"title":"Infallibilism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infallibilism"},{"title":"Epistemic minimalism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistemic_minimalism"},{"title":"Reformed epistemology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argument_from_a_proper_basis"}]

## Justified True Belief (JTB)

Justified true belief (JTB) has traditionally been treated by many philosophers from Plato onward as constituting knowledge.(no content)The JTB account holds that knowledge is equivalent to justified true belief; if all three conditions (justification, truth, and belief) are met of a given claim, then there is knowledge of that claim.

### The Three Components

According to the JTB definition, S knows that p if and only if (1) p is true, (2) S believes that p, and (3) this belief is justified.(no content)Justification is a property of beliefs insofar as they are held blamelessly—in other words, a justified belief is a belief that a person is entitled to hold.

### The Gettier Problem

Despite its long history, the JTB account has faced significant challenges. Edmund Gettier presented counterexamples (called "Gettier-cases") that challenge the justified true belief account of knowledge.(no content)Gettier illustrated through two counterexamples that there are cases where individuals can have a justified, true belief regarding a claim but still fail to know it because the reasons for the belief, while justified, turn out to be false.

A classic example is the "stopped clock case": Alice sees a clock that reads two o'clock and believes that the time is two o'clock. It is, in fact, two o'clock. However, unknown to Alice, the clock she's looking at stopped twelve hours ago.(no content)Alice thus has an accidentally true, justified belief—but most would not say she knows the time.

### Impact on Philosophy

The Gettier problem has "fundamentally altered the character of contemporary epistemology" and has become "a central problem of epistemology since it poses a clear barrier to analyzing knowledge".

Web search results for query: "Induction logic reasoning"

Links: [{"title":"Inductive reasoning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inductive_reasoning"},{"title":"Mathematical induction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_induction"},{"title":"Problem of induction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Problem_of_induction"},{"title":"Inductive logic programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inductive_logic_programming"},{"title":"Logical reasoning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logical_reasoning"},{"title":"Transduction (machine learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transduction_(machine_learning)"},{"title":"Inference - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inference"},{"title":"Pure inductive logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pure_inductive_logic"},{"title":"Inductive reasoning aptitude - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inductive_reasoning_aptitude"},{"title":"Induction puzzles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Induction_puzzles"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of induction logic reasoning:

## Definition

Inductive reasoning is a form of argument that—in contrast to deductive reasoning—allows for the possibility that a conclusion can be false, even if all of the premises are true.

## How It Works

Inductive reasoning starts from a set of individual instances and uses generalization to arrive at a universal law governing all cases, involving the process of inferring a general law or principle from the observations of particular instances. For example, inductive reasoning is a form of generalization that infers a universal law from a pattern found in many individual cases, and can be used to conclude that "all ravens are black" based on many individual observations of black ravens.

## Key Characteristics

Like other forms of non-deductive reasoning, induction is not certain, meaning that the premises support the conclusion by making it more probable but do not ensure its truth.(no content)While deductive logic allows one to arrive at a conclusion with certainty, inductive logic can only provide a conclusion that is probably true.

## Sample Quality Matters

The sample size should be large to guarantee that many individual cases were considered before drawing the conclusion, and an intimately connected factor is that the sample is random and representative.

Inductive reasoning is widely used in everyday life, science, and various professional fields where drawing probable conclusions from observed data is necessary.

Web search results for query: "Lottery paradox"

Links: [{"title":"Lottery paradox - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lottery_paradox"},{"title":"St. Petersburg paradox - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St._Petersburg_paradox"},{"title":"Lottery (decision theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lottery_(decision_theory)"},{"title":"Allais paradox - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allais_paradox"},{"title":"List of paradoxes - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paradoxes_of_infinity"},{"title":"Gambler's fallacy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gambler's_fallacy"},{"title":"Parrondo's paradox - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parrondo's_paradox"},{"title":"Rank-dependent expected utility - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rank-dependent_expected_utility"},{"title":"The Lottery in Babylon - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Lottery_in_Babylon"},{"title":"Winner's curse - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Winner's_curse"}]

## Lottery Paradox

The lottery paradox arises from Henry E. Kyburg Jr. considering a fair 1,000-ticket lottery that has exactly one winning ticket.

### The Core Problem

If an event is considered "very likely" only if the probability of it occurring is greater than 0.99, it is rational to accept that ticket 1 will not win. Since the lottery is fair, it is rational to accept that ticket 2 will not win either, and indeed, it is rational to accept for any individual ticket i that ticket i will not win.

However, accepting that each individual ticket will not win entails that it is rational to accept that no ticket will win, which entails that it is rational to accept the contradictory proposition that one ticket wins and no ticket wins.

### Three Principles in Conflict

It is irrational to accept a proposition that is known to be inconsistent and is jointly inconsistent.

Links: [{"title":"Gettier problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gettier_problem"},{"title":"Edmund Gettier - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edmund_Gettier"},{"title":"List of philosophical problems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unsolved_problems_in_philosophy"},{"title":"Talk:Gettier problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Gettier_problem"},{"title":"Definitions of knowledge - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Definitions_of_knowledge"},{"title":"Talk:List of philosophical problems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:List_of_unsolved_problems_in_philosophy"},{"title":"List of paradoxes - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_paradoxes"},{"title":"Gödel's Loophole - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G%C3%B6del's_Loophole"},{"title":"Paradoxes of set theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paradoxes_of_set_theory"},{"title":"Temporal paradox - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Temporal_paradox"}]

Here's what I found about the Gettier problem:

## Overview

The Gettier problem, in the field of epistemology, is a landmark philosophical problem concerning the understanding of descriptive knowledge.(no content)Attributed to American philosopher Edmund Gettier, Gettier-type counterexamples (called "Gettier-cases") challenge the long-held justified true belief (JTB) account of knowledge.

## The Core Issue

The JTB account holds that knowledge is equivalent to justified true belief; if all three conditions (justification, truth, and belief) are met of a given claim, then there is knowledge of that claim.(no content)In his 1963 three-page paper titled "Is Justified True Belief Knowledge?", Gettier attempts to illustrate by means of two counterexamples that there are cases where individuals can have a justified, true belief regarding a claim but still fail to know it because the reasons for the belief, while justified, turn out to be false.

## Examples

One classic illustration is the stopped clock case: Alice sees a clock that reads two o'clock and believes that the time is two o'clock. It is, in fact, two o'clock. There's a problem, however: unknown to Alice, the clock she's looking at stopped twelve hours ago. Alice thus has an accidentally true, justified belief.

## Impact

John L. Pollock and Joseph Cruz have stated that the Gettier problem has "fundamentally altered the character of contemporary epistemology" and has become "a central problem of epistemology since it poses a clear barrier to analyzing knowledge".(no content)Responses to Gettier's paper have been numerous. Some reject Gettier's examples as inadequate justification, while others seek to adjust the JTB account of knowledge and blunt the force of these counterexamples.

Web search results for query: "Epistemology justification"

Links: [{"title":"Justification (epistemology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Justification_(epistemology)"},{"title":"Category:Justification (epistemology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Justification_(epistemology)"},{"title":"Epistemology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistemology"},{"title":"Internalism and externalism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internalism_and_externalism"},{"title":"Feminist epistemology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feminist_epistemology"},{"title":"Coherentism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coherentism"},{"title":"Regress argument (epistemology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regress_argument_(epistemology)"},{"title":"Epistemic theories of truth - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistemic_theories_of_truth"},{"title":"Infinitism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infinitism"},{"title":"Foundherentism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foundherentism"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about epistemology and justification:

## Definition

Justification (also called epistemic justification) is a property of beliefs that fulfill certain norms about what a person should believe.(no content)Epistemologists often identify justification as a component of knowledge distinguishing it from mere true opinion.

## Role in Knowledge

According to the so-called traditional analysis, knowledge has three components: it is a belief that is justified and true.(no content)Epistemologists study the reasons why someone holds a belief.

## Major Debates

Debates surrounding epistemic justification often involve the structure of justification, including whether there are foundational justified beliefs or whether mere coherence is sufficient for a system of beliefs to qualify as justified.(no content)Another major subject of debate is the sources of justification, which might include perceptual experience (the evidence of the senses), reason, and authoritative testimony, among others.

## Main Theories of Justification

Foundationalism holds that basic beliefs justify other, non-basic beliefs. Epistemic coherentism holds that beliefs are justified if they cohere with other beliefs a person holds, each belief is justified if it coheres with the overall system of beliefs. Other prominent theories include reliabilism, which holds that a belief is justified if it is the result of a reliable process.

## Internalism vs. Externalism

Externalist conceptions of justification assert that facts external to the believer can serve as the justification for a belief. According to the externalist, a believer need not have any internal access or cognitive grasp of any reasons or facts which make their belief justified. In contrast, access internalists require that a believer must have internal access to the justifier(s) of their belief in order to be justified in believing it.

Foundationalism holds that basic beliefs justify other, non-basic beliefs. Epistemic coherentism holds that beliefs are justified if they cohere with other beliefs a person holds, each belief is justified if it coheres with the overall system of beliefs. Other prominent theories include reliabilism, which holds that a belief is justified if it is the result of a reliable process.

## Internalism vs. Externalism

Externalist conceptions of justification assert that facts external to the believer can serve as the justification for a belief. According to the externalist, a believer need not have any internal access or cognitive grasp of any reasons or facts which make their belief justified. In contrast, access internalists require that a believer must have internal access to the justifier(s) of their belief in order to be justified in believing it.

## Analysis Complete! ✅

I've successfully analyzed the paper "Knowledge and Justification" and extracted all key entities and relations. Here's a summary:

**Paper Classification:** `survey` - This is a position paper that develops epistemological theory by examining and synthesizing existing concepts and paradoxes in knowledge studies.

**Triples Extracted (9 total):**

| Entity | Type | Relation | Role in Paper |
|--------|------|----------|---|
| Justified true belief | concept | uses | Foundational framework for analyzing knowledge |
| Justification (epistemology) | concept | uses | Core theory being developed |
| Epistemology | concept | uses | Philosophical discipline grounding the work |
| Foundationalism | concept | uses | Primary epistemological approach employed |
| Deductive reasoning | method | uses | Justification method (insufficient for certainty) |
| Inductive reasoning | method | uses | Justification method (yields only probability) |
| Abductive reasoning | method | uses | Justification method (cannot provide certainty) |
| Lottery paradox | concept | uses | Key paradox analyzed to reveal knowledge tensions |
| Gettier problem | concept | uses | Fundamental challenge to JTB account |

**Validation Result:** ✅ All checks passed - 9 triples with 6 concepts and 3 methods properly documented and verified against Wikipedia URLs.
